node.text: Welcome to the new era of Martian exploration! Yesterday the world looked on in awe as NASA shared the first video of a rover landing on another planet and the first recording of audio from Mars. Listen to our CEO @billnye as he reacts to this unprecedented moment in history.

node.title: Bill Nye on the Perseverance Landing

node.text: Space exploration brings out the best in us. Here are our NASA recommendations for the Biden Administration.

node.title: Bill Nye's Open Letter to President Biden & Vice President Harris

node.text:
115 members traveled to Washington D.C. from 28 states for one massively successful day of action to #FundSpace
•
Will you join us next year? Get involved at planetary.org/advocacy
•
*Note: this event took place over a month ago. We share it today to thank our members for their hard work. •
The Planetary Society moved quickly last week to cancel all in-person meetings, business travel, and become a remote workplace to help #flattenthecurve. Stay healthy, everyone!

node.text: Carl Sagan dreamed of solar sailing before founding The Planetary Society in 1980. Now our members have helped us fulfill that dream. Mission details at planetary.org/lightsail

node.text: It isn’t easy to defend our planet from asteroids. That’s why we support those who step up to the job.

Star Trek: Voyager's holographic doctor, Robert Picardo, also serves on The Planetary Society Board of Directors. However, he is not the first connection between Star Trek and The Planetary Society. In 1980, the creator of Star Trek, Gene Roddenberry, wrote a letter and sent it out to a Star Trek fans mailing list. In the letter, Gene invited his fans to join us on our mission to explore the cosmos.

Hear the letter as read by Robert Picardo, listen to his Jean-Luc Picard impression, and see inside Bill Nye's office for more Star Trek artifacts on hand at The Planetary Society.

Read the full letter at planetary.org

node.title: A rare letter from Star Trek creator Gene Roddenberry

node.text: We can now sail on sunlight in space, just like a sailboat at sea! Our CEO @BillNye explains how.

node.title: Bill Nye explains: A new way to travel space

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Planetary Society on August 20, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
NASA’s Voyager 2 spacecraft launched 44 years ago today, on August 20, 1977. Voyager 1 took off 16 days later but reached a higher velocity and eventually overtook its sister spacecraft. Voyager 1 is now the most distant object ever sent from Earth.

What's the most awesome thing about the Voyager spacecrafts?

(📸 : NASA/JPL-Caltech)

#voyager #space #science #OTD

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Planetary Society on August 20, 2021.

node.text:
You can't always get what you want, but if you try sometimes, you just might end up with the Halley Armada.

Before starting The Planetary Society, our founders advocated for a solar sailing mission to rendezvous with Halley's Comet in 1986. That mission didn't work out, but Russia, Japan and Europe all sent spacecraft to fly by the comet.

@esa's Giotto mission caught this view of Halley's Comet from a distance of just 600 kilometers (373 miles) on March 14, 1986. Giotto was the first spacecraft to get close-up observations of a comet.

What's your favorite comet?

(📸 : Halley Multicolor Camera Team / Giotto Project / ESA)

#comet #space #science

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Planetary Society on August 19, 2021.

node.text:
Happy #WorldPhotographyDay! Here's a photo of the world.

We took this image of northern Brazil from space with our crowdfunded LightSail 2 spacecraft on September 2, 2020. We color-adjusted this image and removed some of the distortion from the camera's 180-degree fisheye lens.

Have you tried processing space images before?

#photography #space #Earth

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Planetary Society on August 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and indoor.

node.text:
Our first attempt at a solar sail wasn't a huge success, but in our defense, its rocket crashed.

On June 21, 2005, our Cosmos 1 spacecraft went into the sea when the first stage of its rocket failed after launch. It was sad, but our members kept working to make our dream of solar sailing a reality.

What's something you're proud of that took years to accomplish?

This image shows Louis Friedman looking over the Cosmos 1 flight unit.

(📸 : Lavochkin Association/The Planetary Society)

#space #science #light

node.text:
Carl Sagan dreamed of solar sailing before founding The Planetary Society in 1980. He appeared on The Tonight Show in 1976 to talk about his hopes for the future of solar sailing technology.

More than 40 years later, we realized that dream with the launch of our crowdfunded LightSail 2 spacecraft, which is designed to propel through space on beams of sunlight.

Do you think Carl would be proud?

#space #sailing #CarlSagan

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Planetary Society on August 17, 2021.

node.text:
Times a solar-powered spacecraft won't work:
-too far from the Sun
-shadowed craters
-two-week-long lunar nights
-Martian dust storms

That's why nuclear-powered spacecraft are so useful!

This image shows a ceramic fuel pellet of Plutonium-238. It glows orange from heat produced by its radioactive decay. These pellets are used inside Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generators (RTGs) to provide heat that is converted into electricity on spacecraft. This particular pellet is about 5cm (2 in) across and 10cm (4 in) tall.

What are some locations in the solar system you would need a nuclear-powered spacecraft to explore?

(📸 : U.S. Department of Energy)

#space #science #energy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Planetary Society on August 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"PROVIDE SHIPS OR SAILS ADAPTED TO THE HEAVENLY BREEZES, AND THERE WILL SOME WHO WILL BRAVE EVEN THAT VOID." -JOHANNES KEPLER BE THEPLANETARYSOCI ETY'.

node.text:
In 1607, Johannes Kepler saw Halley's Comet in the skies over Europe. He wondered what caused the comet's tail to spread across the sky. Sunlight, he thought, must be liberating material from its surface. 

And so begins the story of our crowdfunded LightSail 2 mission.

The notion of the sun's rays interacting with a celestial object led Kepler to believe that a space sail might one day capture sunlight the way a boat sail catches the wind.

A year after Kepler saw Halley's Comet, he wrote this quote in a letter to Galileo Galilei. 

Our crowdfunded LightSail 2 spacecraft would have blown Kepler's mind. What invention do you wish you could share with scientists from centuries past?

#light #sailing #space

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Planetary Society on August 14, 2021.

node.text:
Solar sailing works because light has momentum, even though it has no mass. The momentum gets transferred to the sail, pushing it forward. This quirk of physics may be what someday enables interstellar travel.

Our crowdfunded LightSail 2 spacecraft captured this image of French Guiana, Suriname, Guyana, and the Atlantic Ocean on September 20, 2020. 

#space #light #sailing

node.text:
Venus had an unusually busy week. Two spacecraft popped over for a quick visit. On August 9, @NASA and @europeanspaceagency’s Solar Orbiter whizzed by Venus, followed by ESA and @jaxajp’s BepiColombo spacecraft on August 10. 

In the days leading up to the flyby, Solar Orbiter captured this sped-up view of its approach to the planet.

The back-to-back flybys are exciting because they offer a unique opportunity to study Venus from different vantage points at nearly the same time. They’re also logistically important because both spacecraft need a gravity assist from swinging around Venus to reach their final destinations: the Sun (Solar Orbiter) and Mercury (BepiColombo).

(Vid: ESA/NASA/NRL/SoloHI/Phillip Hess edited by The Planetary Society)

#space #Venus #science

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Planetary Society on August 12, 2021.

node.text:
NASA: Aha! We've solved the mystery of Perseverance's missing Martian rock sample. The rock was just super crumbly.

Mars: And I would have gotten away with it, too, if it weren't for those meddling scientists!

Last week, NASA's Perseverance rover attempted to collect its first rock core on Mars. The process went according to plan, except for one massive problem: it didn't manage to collect any rock.  After carefully looking through the data, the Perseverance team discovered that the rock wasn't robust enough to produce a core, and instead, had crumbled to bits.

But Perseverance will Persevere! The rover will continue to its next sampling location in South Seitah and try again.

(📸 : NASA/JPL-Caltech/MSSS)

#Mars #space #science

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Planetary Society on August 11, 2021. May be an image of nature and sky.

node.text:
The Perseid meteor shower peaks tonight! 

Here's a beautiful picture of the Perseids taken in Sedona, Arizona. ☄️

How's the weather where you live?

(📸 : iStock.com / Diane Kulpinski)

#meteorshower #space #perseidmeteorshower

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Planetary Society on August 10, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
BepiColombo: Hi, Venus! Just stopping by for another gravity assist. Nice to see you. Never coming back! k byeeeeeee -flies away-

BepiColombo made its 2nd flyby of our neighboring planet earlier today. The spacecraft captured this view as it passed the planet for a gravity assist that will bring it closer to its target: Mercury.

BepiColombo is a joint European-Japanese mission. It launched in 2018 and will enter Mercury orbit in 2025. The mission will study water ice at Mercury’s poles and the planet’s abnormally large core.

(📸 : ESA/JAXA)

#space #Venus #science
